topic.title: HP Helion 1.0 Development Platform: Application Lifecycle Service Client Command Reference

section.title: Usage
section.p: helion [options] command [arguments] [command-options]
For more information, use the helion help, helion help [option], or helion options commands.
Many of the informational commands take a --json option if you wish to generate machine-parseable output. In some cases the --json option reveals additional details.
Note that Administrative user privileges are required for some commands.

section.title: helion login
section.p: Logs in to the current or specified target with the named user.

row.entry: The credentials to use. Each use of the option declares a single element, using the form "key: value" for the argument. This is an ALS 3-specific option
The group to use for the login. This is an ALS 2-specific option.
Disable errors generated for missing organization and/or space.
Disable all prompts (interactive queries) that would normally be seen by the user.
The organization to use. This is an ALS 3-specific option. If not specified programmatically, the user is prompted to choose an organization.
The password to use. For ALS 3, this is a shorthand for --credentials 'password:

The space (in the organization) to use. This is an ALS 3-specific option. If not specified the user is prompted to choose among the possible s in the organization if specified. If the organization is not specified, the user is prompted to choose from all spaces in all organizations the user belongs to.
The one-off target to use for the current operation only.
The one-off authentication token to use for the current operation only.
Path to an existing and readable file containing the targets and authorization tokens.
Originally used to activate tracing of the issued REST requests and responses; tracing is always active now. See the trace command to print the saved trace to stdout.

section.title: helion create-app *\<application*
section.p: Create an empty application with the specified configuration.

row.entry: Url of a custom buildpack. This is an Application Lifecycle Service 3 specific option.
The application's start command. Defaults to a framework-specific value if required and not specified by manifest.yml.
The application's per-instance disk allocation. Defaults to a framework-specific value if not specified by manifest.yml.
Environment variable overrides. These are always applied regardless of --env-mode. The mode is restricted to the variable declarations found in the manifest.

Environment replacement mode. One of preserve, or replace. The default is "preserve". Using mode "replace" implies --reset as well, for push. Note that new variables are always set. Preserve only prevents update of existing variables. This setting applies only to the variable declarations found in the manifest. Overrides made with --env are always applied.

Specify the framework to use. Cannot be used together with --no-framework. Defaults to a heuristically chosen value if not specified, and none for --no-framework. This is an Application Lifecycle Service 2 specific option.
The once-off group to use for the current operation. This is a Application Lifecycle Service 2 option.
The number of application instances to create. Defaults to 1, if not specified by a manifest.yml.
Print raw json as output, not human-formatted data.
Path of the manifest file to use. If not specified a search is done.
The application's per-instance memory allocation. Defaults to a framework-specific value if not specified by manifest.yml.
Create application without any framework. Cannot be used together with --framework. This is an Application Lifecycle Service 2 specific option.
The once-off organization to use for the current operation. This is an Application Lifecycle Service 3 option.
Path of the directory holding the application files to push. Defaults to the current working directory.
Analogue of --env-mode, for the regular settings.
The name of the runtime to use. Default is framework specific, if not specified by a manifest.yml. This is an Application Lifecycle Service 2 specific option.
The once-off space to use for the current operation, specified by name. This is an Application Lifecycle Service 3 option. Cannot be used together with --space-guid.
The once-off space to use for the current operation, specified by guid. This is an Application Lifecycle Service 3 option. Cannot be used together with --space.
The OS foundation the application will run on. This is an Application Lifecycle Service 3 specific option.
host:port of the Komodo debugger listener to inject into the application as environment variables.
Request target to stream the log.
The once-off target to use for the current operation.
The once-off authentication token to use for the current operation.
Path to an existing and readable file containing the targets and authorization tokens.
Activate tracing of the issued REST requests and responses. This option is a no-op now. Tracing is always active. See the 'trace' command to print the saved trace to stdout.
The urls to map the application to. I.e. can be specified multiple times.
Set up debugging through an application-specific harbor (port) service. Target version 2.8+ only.

row.entry: The name of the application to push/update the selected application as. Possible only if a single application is pushed or updated.

Links pointing outside of the application directory are copied into the application.
The application's per-instance disk allocation. Defaults to a framework-specific value if not specified by manifest.yml.
Environment variable overrides. These are always applied regardless of --env-mode. The mode is restricted to the variable declarations found in the manifest.

Environment replacement mode. One of preserve, or replace. The default is "preserve". Using mode "replace" implies --reset as well, for push. Note that new variables are always set. Preserve only prevents update of existing variables. This setting applies only to the variable declarations found in the manifest. Overrides made with --env are always applied.
Push, and start the application, even when stopped.

The time the client waits for an application to start before giving up and returning, in seconds. Note that this is measured from the last entry seen in the log stream. The optional suffix 's' stands for seconds.
